page.title: 04Historic Dereham
page.content: The name Dereham means "Deer Enclosure" from Deorhamm, hamm meaning "an enclosed plot" and the town probably got its name from an enclosure made for the deer which were plentiful in the district in Saxon times. Dereham is one of the oldest towns in Norfolk with a history going back 654 A.D. when Saint Withburga is said to have founded a nunnery here. The town's best known historic monument is the site of her tomb in the Parish Churchyard. When the monks of Ely stole her body in 974, a spring said to have healing powers issued from the tomb, which became a centre of pilgrimage. Bonner's cottages, built in 1502 once belonged to the notorious Bishop Bonner, Rector of the Parish in the 16th Century. They are now a small museum.
